_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary - Risk Management Plan

Coffeyville Resources Nitrogen Fertilizers, LLC.

March 7, 2011

Introduction

The Coffeyville Resources Nitrogen Fertilizer Plant ("CRNF Plant") is located on 72 acres at the northeast corner of the City of Coffeyville in Montgomery county Kansas.  The plant primarily manufactures anhydrous ammonia and urea-ammonium nitrate ("UAN") solutions.  Several processes within the CRNF Plant contain more than a threshold quantity of a regulated substance; therefore, this facility is subject to the United States Environmental Protection Agency ("USEPA") Risk Management Program ("RMP") rules under the Clean Air Act Amendments ("CAAA") of 1990.

The following is the Executive Summary of the RMP for the CRNF Plant.

Facility Overview

The CRNF Plant is a nitrogen fertilizer-manufacturing complex producing anhydrous ammonia and UAN solutions.  The complex produces for market approximately 670,000 tons of UAN and 145,000 tons of anhydrous ammonia annually for use as agricultural fertilizers.  The design of the facility, which started production in July 2000, incorporates state-of-the-art safety and environmental controls for the protection of the employees and the surrounding community.  

The facility consists of an air separation unit, a gasification unit, a Selexol unit, a hydrogen purification unit, an ammonia synthesis unit, a urea unit, a nitric acid unit,  an ammonium nitrate-UAN unit, and storage and loading units for ammonia and UAN.  The air separation unit, while located on the CRNF site, is independently owned and operated by Linde Gases.  The air separation unit makes high purity oxygen and nitrogen for use in the gasification and ammonia production units.  In addition, Linde markets these gases along with argon to off-site customers. 

The gasification unit produces hydrogen gas using the GE Energy Hydrogen Generation Process.  The gasifier produces raw hydrogen and carbon oxides by the partial oxidation of petroleum coke wi

th oxygen in the presence of water.  The petroleum coke is provided primarily by the neighboring Coffeyville Resources Refining and Marketing, LLC ("CRRM") Refinery and supplemented with coke from other locations.  The hydrogen is purified by shift conversion of carbon monoxide to carbon dioxide, the removal of hydrogen sulfide and carbon dioxide in the Selexol unit, and removal of trace contaminants using pressure swing adsorption in the hydrogen purification unit.

In the ammonia synthesis unit the hydrogen from the hydrogen purification unit reacts with nitrogen from the air separation unit to make anhydrous ammonia.  The ammonia is either sold for direct fertilizer applications or upgraded for UAN solutions.  Ammonia along with by-product carbon dioxide removed from the hydrogen in the Selexol unit is used to produce liquid urea in the urea unit.  In the nitric acid unit, ammonia and air are also used to produce a weak nitric acid solution that is subsequently neutralized with ammonia to produce ammonium nitrate.  The liquid urea and ammonium nitrate are mixed forming the urea-ammonium nitrate solution product in the UAN unit. Ammonia and UAN solutions can be shipped to bulk distributors by both truck and railcar.  On-site storage tanks have been constructed to safely hold the ammonia and UAN products based on seasonal demand requirements.

Pollution Prevention Policy

CRNF is committed to protecting the environment and preserving our natural resources for future generations by pursuing elimination or reduction of our use of toxic substances and minimizing our use of energy and generation of wastes to the extent technically and economically feasible.  CRNF strives to prevent the generation of pollution at the source, but, where that cannot be achieved, CRNF is committed to environmentally sound methods of recycling, treatment, and disposal.  By preventing pollution at the source, we strive to achieve cost savings, increase operational efficiencies, improve the q

uality of our products and services, maintain a safe and healthful workplace, and improve the environment.

The above goals were applied to the design and construction of the CRNF Plant.  The gasification process substitutes high grade feedstock (natural gas) with a low-grade feedstock (petroleum coke -- the end product from the condensation process in oil cracking with poor fuel characteristics).  Substituting coke for natural gas in our process conserves over 10 billion cubic feet of natural gas per year, which can be used for home heating, electrical power generation, or in the production of other materials.  The reliable source of raw material from the adjacent refinery reduces the energy required to transport the coke and allows for the potential return of energy or raw materials to the refinery.

The environmental design objective for this plant was to achieve significant emission reduction compared to the conventional nitrogen plant.  No hazardous solids are produced during normal operations.  The water effluent is sufficiently clean to enter the Coffeyville's municipal water treatment system.  


Stationary Source and Regulated Substances

The Selexol unit, ammonia synthesis unit, urea unit, refrigerated atmospheric ammonia storage tank, pressurized ammonia bullet tanks, and water treatment constitute the processes covered by the USEPA RMP rule.  Regulated substances held in covered processes above the threshold quantity include anhydrous ammonia in the Selexol unit, ammonia synthesis unit, urea unit, refrigerated atmospheric ammonia storage tank, and pressurized ammonia bullet tanks and chlorine in water treatment.  Chlorine is used as a biological control agent in the cooling water systems associated with the production units.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy

The management and employees of this facility are committed to the prevention of any accidental releases.  It is this facility's policy to eliminate significant accidental

releases of any substance, in particular hazardous and regulated substances, as well as strive to eliminate to the extent possible even minor and inconsequential releases of any type.  Prevention of accidental releases is critical to the safe operation of this plant, to the safety of its employees, and to the safety of the general public.

To achieve these goals of accident and accidental release prevention, the facility is committed to the following:

--    A knowledgeable, highly trained, and motivated employee group
--    A well designed facility that is maintained and operated in a superior manner
--    Improvements that enhance safety and accident prevention where appropriate
--    A superior safety and accident record as the result of an excellent safety program
--    Preparation and training for emergency response and mitigation

The CRNF Plant has a combined written Emergency Response Plan that covers both the CRNF Plant and the adjacent CRRM Refinery.  CRNF and CRRM are committed to response and mitigation of any accidental release to minimize the impact to employees, the community, and environment.  The response plan is coordinated with adjacent operating facilities [Linde and Tessenderlo Kerley ("TKI")], Local Emergency Planning Committee ("LEPC"), and emergency response agencies.  Employees are trained in the implementation of the plan and in response activities that could be required in the event of an emergency.  Refresher training is provided to employees on a regular basis.


Chemical Specific Prevention Program

Covered processes at the CRNF Plant are subject to the Occupational Health and Safety Administration ("OSHA") Process Safety Management ("PSM") rule codified in Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations ("CFR") Part 1910 Subpart H ("29 CFR 1910.119"), because these covered processes contain more than the threshold quantity of a highly hazardous chemical.  Therefore, under the USEPA RMP rule these processes are considered Program 3 covered processes and must fo

llow Program 3 Prevention Program requirements.

The OSHA PSM/USEPA RMP Prevention Program consists of a set of facility management policies and procedures which promote and recognize process safety and the prevention of accidents in plants that handle, use, store, and process hazardous chemical materials.  The procedures address all aspects of plant activities including training, maintenance, operating procedures, process reviews, mechanical integrity, safe work practices, incident investigation, program audits, and other activities in a manner to provide controls to prevent errors, failures, and inadvertent changes in a process that could result in accidents.

The covered processes at the CRNF Plant adhere to the requirements of PSM and have written policies and procedures addressing all aspects of PSM and applicable USEPA RMP Prevention Programs.  The facility has addressed the elements of accident prevention included in these programs.

The CRNF PSM/RMP Program consists of several elements and policies which are briefly outlined below.

--    Employee Participation - Employees are involved in all aspects of the program and are provided any information developed in the program.  Employees participate in process reviews, assist with development of procedures, and all other aspects of the program.

--    Process Safety Information ("PSI") - All necessary process information and records are accessible to employees including information on the hazards of the chemicals, process technology with safe operating limits, and equipment records and design requirements.

--    Process Hazard Analysis ("PHA") - Process hazard analysis and review has been conducted by employee teams to identify and correct any perceived hazards.  These reviews are updated every five years or more often if changes indicate the necessity of additional review.

--    Operating Procedures - Operating procedures are prepared for all aspects of operation including emergency operation and shutdown, operating limi

ts and methods to correct or avoid deviations from specified limits, safety and health considerations for process operations and the chemicals involved, and safety system operation and function.

--    Operator Training - All operators receive initial training in the process and its operating procedures and continue to receive refresher training at least every three years.  In reality, operator training is a continual and ongoing process.  Operator training includes on-the-job training ("OJT") with experienced operators and also classroom-type instruction.

--    Contractors - Contractor selection includes review of the Contractor's safety performance and programs.  Contractors are oriented to known hazards in the facility and the emergency plan and are required to adhere to facility safe work practice procedures.  Contractor performance is periodically evaluated as necessary to ensure work is completed in a safe and correct manner.

--    Pre-startup Safety Review ("PSSR") - Initial safety reviews were conducted on the CRNF facility before startup.  Additional pre-startup safety reviews are made for any significant modification to a covered process that requires a change in PSI prior to startup to ensure that construction and equipment is installed in accordance with design; all necessary procedures including safety, operating, maintenance and emergency procedures are in place; training is completed; and that hazard analysis and requirements of management of change are completed.

--    Mechanical Integrity ("MI") - Procedures for inspection and testing and correction of equipment deficiencies have been prepared.  A quality assurance procedure assures equipment, parts, materials, and installations are suitable for the applications intended.  Maintenance employees are trained in the process hazards and in safety procedures applicable to their work.

--    Safe Work Practices - Procedures and policies for work permits and maintenance and operating actions are in place for accident

prevention.

--    Management of Change ("MOC") - No changes are allowed to the process or procedures without review and authorization.  Safety impacts, technical basis, required procedure modification, and training are all considered in the review.  The MOC process is used to verify the safety of the change and to prevent unintended consequences as a result of change.

--    Incident Investigation - Any incident which results in a significant chemical release, or could have reasonably resulted in such a release, is promptly investigated by a facility team.  Findings of the investigation and recommendations for corrective action are documented as are the resolution of the recommendations and corrective actions.

--    Emergency Planning and Response - The PSM/ RMP Prevention Program includes the combined CRNF/CRRM facility Emergency Response Plan.

--    Compliance Audit - The PSM program and RMP results are audited at least every three years to verify compliance with these procedures.  Findings of the audit, if any, are documented and any deficiencies are corrected and documented.  The audit is conducted by persons knowledgeable of the facility processes but not directly connected with the facility.

The facility is diligent in adhering to and maintaining its PSM/RMP Prevention Program.

Emergency Response Plan

The CRNF Plant has a combined written Emergency Response Program that covers both the CRNF Plant and the adjacent CRRM refinery.  This plan meets the requirements of the RMP rule and other USEPA and OSHA rules.  This Plan is coordinated with Linde, TKI, the LEPC, and is available to the responding agencies.  Emergency planning and Community Right-To-Know information as required under SARA Title III is provided to the State Emergency Response Commission, LEPC, and other appropriate agencies such as the local fire department.

The facility is an active participant in the Local Emergency Planning Committee and interacts with various local agencies in its emergency plannin

g such as local fire departments; law enforcement agencies such as the police, highway patrol, and sheriff's office; and hospitals.

Employees receive annual training in the response plan and also receive a variety of safety training - both general and in the competencies relative to their required roles in the plan.  Periodically the plan will be practiced in a tabletop classroom type setting and also tested in mock emergencies including participation by outside responding agencies.

5-Year Accident History

The facility investigated three accidental releases during the past five years that met the RMP rule definition and/or had a potential RMP off-site impact.  The first accidental release occurred on 8-6-2007 and resulted in several contract employees from the adjacent refinery being treated for exposure to ammonia and damage to process equipment.  An incident investigation was conducted and actions taken on identified correctable opportunities.

The second accidental release occurred on 11-1-2008 and resulted in a public road being closed for a short period of time but did not result in any injuries or personnel exposures.

The third accidental release occurred on 9-30-2010 and resulted in on-site property damage of approximately 6.5 million dollars, off-site property damage of approximately five thousand dollars, evacuation of CRNF non-essential personnel, a shelter-in-place, and off-site injuries to approximately 50 people which required medical treatment.  An incident investigation was conducted and actions taken on identified correctable opportunities 

Planned Changes for Safety Improvements

Safety improvements continue as an ongoing process at the facility and are facilitated by the PSM/RMP Prevention Program.   Some of the initiatives for continuing improvement of the safety/environmental/RMP programs include:
--    Training in incident investigation methods for identified personnel;
--    Additional audits of MOC documentation by the PSM Coordinator;
--    Signi

ficant revisions to the MOC and PSSR procedures with additional training for identified plant personnel;
--    Operating procedures are being upgraded continuously and are accessible electronically by all affected employees.  Various types of graphics continue to be added to the operating procedures where appropriate to assist in operator training/understanding.
--    Maintenance procedures and training are also being upgraded on a continuous basis.

Changes relevant to the safety of plant personnel and equipment and the reduction of environmental emissions occur continuously as needs are identified through constant review of the MOC procedures, operator training, incident investigation, and mechanical integrity programs.
